Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learn how to analyze games, determine strategies, etc..
You learn game theory concepts and how to solve games. It's a lot of fun.

This was a very challenging course.  However, the concepts were very interesting.  I acquired a lot of economic insight that I feel is a bit niche, however it was interesting to take this course because it taught about a different way of thinking and forced me to apply my knowledge of economics in an entirely different way than I had before.
I learned the basics of game theory: what a game is, what dominant strategies are, what Nash Equilibria are, and how to solve many different types of games in a theoretical setting.
How to cope with stress

How to solve for nash equilibria - regular, mixed, subgame perfect, bayesian, etc in static and dynamic games of perfect and imperfect information. Auctions, bargaining, cartels. Basically if you're given any game where the payoffs are known, you will be able to figure out the optimal strategy.

In Game Theory, you learn matrix decision-making, auction theory, evolutionary game theory, sustaining cooperation, signaling games, and other strategic applications. It's really an interesting course and Professor Halac was a great lecturer.
Obviously learned game theoretic principles and learned how to solve a lot of games with increasingly difficult set-ups.

A better understanding of decision making in the game theory framework, which has applications in day-to-day life (as well as in large global policy decisions and that kind of thing). A new way of thinking about these things.
This class improved my ability to think rationally and logically. I see myself using this kind of thinking in my daily life in the future.
Not much, its mostly just basic probability.
Game theory as the name states!
Perhaps my favourite course this semester. Very illuminating view of rational decision making and game theory. Excellent instructors also.

This course was absolutely fascinating, and incredibly insightful into rational human behavior and the way we interact with one another. While certainly quite a challenging course, I am nonetheless very glad to have taken it. If you take this class, it teaches you about cooperation, and cooperate you must in order to sift through the work of this class.
Logical problem-solving.
Basic game theory knowledge in Nash Equilibrium, bargaining, auctions, and evolutionary game theory.
Game theory foundaions and interesting applications
I learned how to consider a multi-actor interaction in the context of a game, and how to use rationality and expectation to uncover the outcome of these games
This course was a great way to gain a new perspective on how to problem solve and to think critically through decisions.
basic knowledge of game theory. This class, as with all introductory economics classes, teaches you to teach yourself.
This course covers many game theory models.
Knowledge of Game theory.
How to think strategically and anticipate the competition's next move.
Pretty solid course.
It's a solid course, would be much better if we had one professor the whole semester. It was kind of annoying to switch mid-semester.

I think it would be preferable if every problem set were graded instead of just four. I had no incentive to try on the other problem sets that were not graded, and overly pressured to do well on the ones that were graded. The final exam was very reasonable.

I thought the first half of the course could have been facilitated in a way that made learning more engaging.  Maria should talk to Marina to pick up some ways to keep the class more engaged and make the material easier for us to understand.

The material of the class was its biggest strength. It progressed in a very clear, logical manner, and started from the basics to build up to some very complicated topics that could actually be applied to the real world. I thought the material was good, but class was never always engaging.
Strengths - It's a very interesting topic. And Marina is a good lecturer. Weaknesses - not many, maybe too slow initially for some people but it picks up.

Strengths of the course include devoted professors, helpful TF's, interesting material, and none to challenging math nor assessments. Weaknesses are that the psets are usually beyond what was covered in class and require outside research, plus the TF's are not "supposed" to help with the graded problem sets.
The Problem sets were helpful for exercising the concepts learned in class. However, sometimes we would not cover much in section which seems like a wasted opportunity.

Not always consistent grading across problem sets. Other than that I don't have any major complaints about the structure of the course. I think it facilitated student learning well. Both Professors gave engaging lectures and there were ample opportunities to practice the material.

I thought the four graded problem sets and weekly non-graded problem sets were a strength of the course. They kept you engaged on a weekly basis and let you know if you were falling behind without the pressure of an eight-hour assignment every week like some other classes. This class had few weaknesses, but the sections were not very useful.
The class is taught with a mindset of "these are some equations worth memorizing" no proof is ever given.
This is a great and intellectually stimulating course!
Excellent lectures and lecture notes. Good course structure.

This class was taught according to incredibly fascinating material. The pace was rather fast, but this is not necessarily a bad thing. The presentations were useful, but the format of only grading four problems sets, I believe, was a mistake. I would rather have had all my problem sets graded to spread out their grade weight. I wish office hours could be more helpful in terms of understanding the material as it is relevant to problem sets. Although I understand that the TAs cannot simply help us with our problem sets, many of hte problem sets involved modifications of the material we had gone over in class, so sometimes making that jump was difficult.

Strength: learn about a very different aspect of economics that can produce a lot of counter-intuitive results that can be seen in the real world 


One weakness in the midterm was that if you set up the first part of the question wrong all subsequent parts were also wrong. I took 122 (intermediate macro) last semester and one nice part about the exams was that the answer was kind of given and you had to find a way to get there, which I think would be a more fair assessment than the high-stakes way these exams are set up.
Decent lectures and assignments.
After mid-semester, powerpoint presentations were not accompanied by material notes, which I found very helpful in the first half of the course.
I really liked the course and how it was structured, but I wish that every pset was graded so that a bad grade on one wouldn't be worth so much of the final grade.

This course was taught by two professors and I think it would have been more effective with just one for the entire semester. There would have been more consistency in teaching style and in the course in general. The strength of the course was the range of questions that we were able to cover from business to biology; we had the opportunity to connect game theory to a lot of different fields of study and this was really interesting.
The first instructor, Maria Saez, was very unclear and disorganized. The course would be improved if only one instructor taught it.

The course could be improved by making problem sets graded and having sections cover something other than the previous problem set. If problem sets are graded, then there would be no need to go over problem sets in section. Instead, section could be used to go over different problems.

Strengths: clear structure and expectations. Weaknesses, at times the course is too slow, at other times too fast. The change of instructors is confusing. Personally, I have liked Prof. Saez much better and was sad to lose her after midterm.
Fascinating content, perhaps could have provided more ways in which the concepts could be applied to the real world.
Not a life changing class but a good one. Interesting material that encourages you to think in a particular and important way.
Yeah, it's a fun econ elective for sure.

Not really econ enough to be an econ class, not really math enough to be a math class, but it's interesting material so I would recommend it if you need it for your major. If you are only interested in learning about game theory just for fun, then I would probably recommend just getting a good book on it, or watching YouTube videos.

If this course if fixed so that Marina teaches the whole thing or so that the first half of the semester is somehow made more like the second half, then yes, I would consider recommending this class to another student as long as they're up for the challenge because overall, the concepts regarding decision making that we learned in this course is extremely interesting!!
Yes - I took this class to fulfill my social science requirement and it did not disappoint. The workload was pretty light and some of the topics we covered are really interesting.

This class was stressful. Fundamentally, I think the material was really interesting, but whenever we had to turn in a graded pset or when it came time for the tests...oh mah lawrd. Stressssss. I thought I was the only one, but when you have a study group of like 8 and everyone is confused about what's going on, you start to think....yknow I'm probably still dumb and all, but like, maybe it's not just me that feels lost?? Forming a study group for this class is essential. A lot of this class, especially in the first half of the semester, was honestly just teaching yourself from the slides. Marina was seriously a g though in the second half of the semester, she's pretty dope. 

I'm going to assume if you're reading this, you have to take this class for a requirement anyways, and to you I say: the class is not THAT bad at all. Like it's honestly fine. But if you don't have to take this for a requirement, I'd say just save yourself the trouble and probably take something else.
Definitely take this if you're at all interested in game theory (I took it for fun as a non-major). It's not a lot of work and it's not too hard, but you'll learn a lot.

Yes, it's a great course. The problem sets are difficult but the TF's will help you answer them correctly. Be prepared to devote quite a few hours to the graded ones. The midterm was challenging, but the final was comparatively easy. Marina Halac is a great lecturer. No complex math involved and the class provided a reprieve from purely economics material.
Yes interesting course that really does change the way you think about most issues in the world.

I was taking this class for a QR credit (wanted an interesting, manageable coursenot a gut!), so I think I was in the minority as a random humanities major, but I enjoyed it. Game theory is an interesting discipline within economics. The workload was totally manageable and both the midterm and the final were quite fair. Adds an interesting perspective to every day life and decision making, which is cool.

This is the best econ class that I've taken at Yale. I was excited to go to lecture, the problem sets were fair and the material was fascinating. The workload is very manageable and Saez and Halac both explained the material well in lecture.
If you're an Econ major, I'm sure it's okay, but as a math major, I was pretty disappointed.
I WOULD DEFINITELY RECOMMEND THIS COURSE!
Yes.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. It is challenging, but a sort of challenging that motivates you to work in the class. The material is incredibly relevant to anyone's life, and it presents a good challenge for a student who might not normally take this sort of course.

Solid econ elective with an average-to-low workload (only 4 graded psets), starts out kind of slow (although the midterm was still not easy) but the material is fairly complex and rewarding to grasp by the end.
Depends on the professor.
Definitely!

Yes, absolutely. This is a great course for everybody to take, because it helps you think about interpersonal interactions in a very interesting way. Great instructors, fair evaluations, and fun content!

I would recommend this course to students who are mathematically minded and enjoy seeing the world through numbers. As the class progresses throughout the semester, more math is introduced and this can be a little challenging if you are not expecting to use numbers for the course. I think the course is organized in a way that encourages learning the material more than doing the work. There are a lot of problem sets that are not graded with only four graded ones. This encouraged students to learn for the sake of learning and not so much for the grade. At the same time, this could be a little dangerous too as there is less incentive to work through the ungraded problem sets thoroughly.
Yes for a requirement.
Yes. Game theory is quite fun!
Yes. If they are interested in Game theory.
Yes but prepare for a lot of work. Worth it in the end, makes you think in a much more thoughtful way.
